title: Pharmaceutical Drug Design
scenario: A chemist is designing a new analgesic (painkiller). The drug must cross the blood-brain barrier, bind to pain receptors, and be metabolised safely.
content:
Drug design relies heavily on organic chemistry. The blood-brain barrier is crossed by lipophilic (non-polar) molecules. Functional groups determine receptor binding: amine groups (−NH₂) interact with receptor proteins via hydrogen bonding and ionic interactions. Metabolism occurs in the liver where cytochrome P450 enzymes oxidise organic compounds.

Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) is a classic example: the acetyl group makes it less irritating than salicylic acid; hydrolysis in the body releases salicylate, which inhibits COX enzymes, reducing prostaglandin synthesis and inflammation.
guided_questions: Why must a drug crossing the blood-brain barrier be relatively non-polar?
What functional groups in aspirin make it acidic? What is its approximate pKₐ?
Describe the hydrolysis reaction of aspirin in the body and identify the products.
what_you_learned: Pharmaceutical chemistry applies organic functional group chemistry, acid-base theory, and biochemical reaction mechanisms to design molecules that interact precisely with biological targets.
